byline.contributor: Emily Palmer reported from Waveland, and Campbell Robertson from New Orleans
byline.original: By EMILY PALMER and CAMPBELL ROBERTSON

abstract: Mississippi is fighting to avoid becoming first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership and outside group hired to run it, following years of dysfunction and failure to repair ailing system; state's Division of Family and Children's Services was subject of 2004 class-action lawsuit for failing to protect children, but has admitted it never complied with requirements of settlements made in 2008 and later.

headline.print_headline: Mississippi Fights to Keep Control of Its Child Welfare System
headline.main: Mississippi Fights to Keep Control of Its Beleaguered Child Welfare System

snippet: After failing to comply with a 2004 lawsuit, Mississippi is trying to avoid becoming the first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership.
lead_paragraph: After failing to comply with a 2004 lawsuit, Mississippi is trying to avoid becoming the first state to have its child welfare system put in receivership.
